title: Sale Fell Walk Route

images.title: Bob Jenkins / Ascending Sale Fell
images.caption: Ascending Sale Fell. The northern end of Bassenthwaite Lake is just visible. The path offers a steady climb, later contouring round the fell and making a pleasant round trip with an option to visit the summit.

images.title: Track around Sale Fell by Jim Barton, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Track around the fell

images.title: Michael Graham / Dodd Crag
images.caption: Dodd Crag. On the southern slope of Sale Fell

images.title: Michael Graham / Summit Cairn, Sale Fell
images.caption: Summit Cairn. Looking towards the coast

images.title: Bob Jenkins / Sale Fell to Lothwaite
images.caption: View to Lothwaite. Appearing as a secondary top, Lothwaite surprisingly extends the top of Sale Fell in a most pleasant manner.

images.title: Bob Jenkins / Descending Sale Fell
images.caption: Descending the fell. The Solway Firth is in the distance, with Criffel in Scotland just visible extreme right.

images.title: St Margaret's Church, Wythop by Jim Barton, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: St Margaret's Church, Wythop. The old church is near the start of the walk.

images.title: Track contouring Sale Fell by Jim Barton, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Grassy Track contouring the fell

description: This circular walk climbs to Sale Fell near Cockermouth in the Lake District National Park. You can start the walk from the parking area just to the west of Bassenthwaite Lake at Wythop. From here you can pick up footpaths heading west up to Dodd Crag before turning east to visit the Sale Fell summit which stands at a height of 359 m (1,178 ft). There's great views back down to Bassenthwaite and over to the surrounding fells, including Skiddaw and Helvellyn. The Isle of Man and the Solway Coast are also visible on a clear day. After taking in the views the route then descends back to the parking area via an old quarry.
